result.execSummary:
The defendant Earl Nelson was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Retail Theft - Intentionally Take (<=$500) [Modifiers: Repeater], a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 943.50(1m)(b).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes:
Costs due during period of supervision. If probation is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, in addition to all other enforecement sanctions available to the court, a civil judgment enforceable by all creditors' remedies shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and governmental entitltes for the balance due.
Submit to DNA sample forthwith

timeConds.notes:

superMiscConds.notes: Outstanding financial obligations shall be paid from inmate wages at the maximum rate allowed for court costs,and the balance due as a condition of extended supervision.  If extended supervision is revoked of will discharge with financial obligations owing, a judgment shall be entered.

Any counseling deemed appropriate by agent. 
Maintain full-time employment.

Defendant Earl Nelson in court with attorney Jamie McClendon.  Defendant in custody. Jeffrey A Sisley appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Counsel requesting new counsel be appointed stating there has been difficulty communicating with defendant. Defendant requests to proceed with plea/sentencing without counsel. Court will allow Atty McClendon to withdraw. Court examines defendant and accepts oral waiver of attorney. Plea questionaire filed. Court examines defendant, accepts change of plea and finds defendant guilty. Recommendation given by the State. Statement by defendant. Court renders sentence.
